title: Insights from present distribution of an alpine mammal Royle's pika (Ochotona roylei) to predict future climate change impacts in the Himalaya
abstract: Climate change poses a major threat to the survival of alpine mammals living in fragmented habitats with poor dispersal abilities. Among these important prey species, pikas are considered especially vulnerable to rising temperatures that would impede their surface activity and dispersal. We investigated how climatic regimes influence the niche of the Royle's pika (Ochotona roylei), and which climatic drivers and change trajectories may threaten the species' future sustenance, thereby prioritizing areas for future conservation of this species across its distribution range. We used Royle's pika presence locations in the MaxEnt framework, along with biologically relevant climatic and topographical variables, to model the present (2010) and the future (2050, 2070) climatic niche under different future scenarios projected by CCSM4 climatic models. Subsequently, we estimated the climatic niche loss across the elevation gradient, longitudinal gradient, and both inside and outside protected areas for all countries within the species' range. Niche suitability of the Royle's pika was substantially determined by precipitation of the coldest quarter (~snow cover) and wettest quarter (~monsoon rainfall). As these parameters are known to be vulnerable to global climatic change, our projection revealed significant loss (102 km 2 /year) in the species niche availability across all future scenarios, particularly in non-protected low-elevation regions. By identifying areas where species survival may be threatened, we confirmed that the distribution of Royle's pika, an important prey species, might be reduced by climate change. Our findings can aid in conservation planning strategies for this species and other alpine fauna and contribute to ongoing efforts to monitor change in the Himalaya.

body_text.text: A central theme in ecology is to understand the patterns and processes that shape species distribution at different spatiotemporal scales (Hutchinson 1965) . Contemporary climatic changes have threatened the persistence of these diverse ecological patterns and processes, particularly for species in high-elevation environments (Pounds et al. 1999; Walther et al. 2005) . Montane environments vary markedly in climate (at both seasonal and diurnal scales) and display pronounced fluctuations in precipitation, ultraviolet (UV) radiation, temperature, and atmospheric pressure. As a result, mountaindwelling species typically exhibit high phenological, reproductive, and behavioral plasticity (Inouye et al. 2000) . However, the degree to which these mountain-dwelling species could adapt or migrate under the contemporary rates of climate change remains questionable, as species will likely face biological challenges (e.g., predation risk, thermal stress) while migrating across previously unoccupied or unsuitable areas (Inouye et al. 2000; Walther et al. 2005) . Ecological niche models offer an opportunity to statistically and spatially simulate the potential effects of future environmental Editor: Wolfgang Cramer Electronic supplementary material The online version of this article (https://doi.org/10.1007/s10113-019-01556-x) contains supplementary material, which is available to authorized users.
conditions on the distribution of montane species and are therefore increasingly used in climate change research (Guisan and Zimmermann 2000; Elith et al. 2006) .

Many montane species are elusive or rare, which results in additional challenges when using niche models, because the species occurrence data that forms the primary information for ecological niche modeling may be sparse or spatially biased. To address these issues, there has been a recent surge in statistical operations pre and post ecological niche modeling, as well as the development of rigorous modeling filters (Allouche et al. 2006; Peterson et al. 2008; Cobos et al. 2019) . One such approach is MaxEnt (Phillips et al. 2006) , which has gained in popularity and has shown to be robust in developing accurate ecological niche models for a variety of species (Elith et al. 2011 ). However, MaxEnt and similar approaches have been criticized for considering presence-only data, thus being vulnerable to niche over-prediction (Segurado and Araujo 2004) . Alternative approaches, such as generalized linear models, generalized additive models, etc., remain limited in use due to the obligatory requirement of presenceabsence data (Araújo and Peterson 2012) . Information on confirmed absence of rare and elusive montane species distributed in isolated habitats across large landscapes (e.g., Himalayan arc) is often scarce, and an intensive sampling framework is required to correct detection biases (e.g., MacKenzie et al. 2002) . Hence, niche models based on presence-only data remain a valuable method in spite of their widely recognized limitations (Guisan and Thuiller 2005) . In particular, when considering small alpine mammals with limited dispersal abilities, presence-only models offer a great opportunity to project the effect of contemporary climatic changes and prioritize areas for active conservation.

Recent research has indicated that small, alpine mammals, such as pikas (Ochotona spp.), are vulnerable to climatic changes (Moritz et al. 2008) . Since pikas are sensitive to heat stress and rely upon access to cooler microclimates to behaviorally thermoregulate. Beever et al. (2003) reported that rapid climate change during the latter part of the twentieth century led to localized extirpations of the American pika (Ochotona princeps). A projected increase in temperature (up to 6°C) by the mid-twenty-first century may cause further range reductions for this alpine mammal, resulting in additional extirpations at lower-elevation habitats (Beever et al. 2010; Calkins et al. 2012) . A similar study in Asia projected a 27% decrease in extent and 640 m upslope retraction in suitable habitat for seven pika species in the Himalaya (Leach et al. 2015) . However, these results are drawn from a very low number of species occurrence records that encompass only a small portion of the current species distribution. For example, Leach et al. (2015) used only 22 locations to model the distribution of Royle's pika (Ochotona roylei), one of the most common talus-dwelling lagomorph species in the Himalayan parts of India, China, Nepal, and Pakistan. The ecological niche model for this species misclassified several prime habitats in the western Himalayan region as less suitable (Bhattacharyya et al. 2014a; . Interpretation of ecological niche models based on such limited datasets has been shown to be problematic in the past (Yackulic et al. 2013) and can underestimate the impacts of climate change.

The Himalaya is one of the world's most vulnerable ecosystems to contemporary climate change, with projected changes including warmer winters, higher precipitation in summers, and a high rate of glacier retreat (Shrestha et al. 2012; Kulkarni and Karyakarte 2014) . These climatic changes may have already influenced climate-sensitive small mammals (e.g., pikas) in the region but have remained unnoticed in the absence of published evidences. With this context, we used Royle's pika (Fig. 1) as a model species to investigate how ongoing climatic changes might influence the species distribution across its range. Royle's pika is a rock talus habitat specialist species, distributed throughout the Himalayan region at elevations ranging from 2400 to 5000 m. Similar to other lagomorphs, Royle's pika does not hibernate and feeds upon plants commonly found along the talusvegetation interface throughout the year. Pikas are considered to be an ideal species for field observation because they are diurnal, easily detected, and leave distinct indirect evidence, such as piles of round scat droppings (Beever et al. 2010; Bhattacharyya and Ray 2015; Bhattacharyya et al. 2014a, b) . Additionally, Royle's pika is an important prey item for several carnivores such as yellow-throated marten (Martes flavigula), Himalayan weasel (Mustela sibirica), snow leopard (Panthera uncia), and red fox (Vulpes vulpes) in alpine and subalpine ecosystems in the Himalayan region (Roberts and Bernhard 1977; Oli et al. 1994) . Previous studies have investigated Royle's pika ecology, habitat and food preferences, and gene flow across the Himalayan region (Kawamichi 1968; Bhattacharyya 2013; Bhattacharyya et al. 2010 Bhattacharyya et al. , 2013 Bhattacharyya et al. , 2014a Bhattacharyya et al. , b, 2015 . However, no study has yet investigated its distribution In order to model the influence of climatic parameters and ongoing climatic changes on the global niche availability of Royle's pika, we used a MaxEnt modeling approach (Phillips et al. 2006) . Based on a priori information, we hypothesized that Royle's pika distribution will be influenced by winter precipitation patterns (Bhattacharyya et al. 2014a; Leach et al. 2015) , summer temperatures (Bhattacharyya et al. 2014b) , and habitat topographical features such as ruggedness (Bhattacharyya et al. 2014a . Since 1980, there has been rapid global environmental change, particularly in the context of rising temperatures in high-elevation areas (Hughes 2000) . Therefore, we used two sets of species presence records (the first: prior to 1980, and second: 1980 onwards) and modeled the contemporary climatic niche availability and the future climatic niche availability under various socio-economic scenarios. We further compared species presence before 1980 with its present and future niche areas, as well as trends in niche availability changes projected across an elevational, longitudinal gradient and areas of differing protected status. By doing this, we identified protected areas where this important prey species may face a significant loss in niche availability under future climatic regimes. Study results can aid in the development of population monitoring and conservation actions for managers in these regions.

Royle's pika is currently distributed in northwestern Pakistan, and the Himalayan regions of India, Nepal, and adjacent Tibet (China) (Bhattacharyya and Smith 2018) . Pika occurrence (n = 142, Fig. 2 ) was recorded by multiple habitat surveys within and outside protected areas (e.g., national parks, wildlife sanctuaries, biosphere reserves) in the Indian state of Uttarakhand (e.g., Kedarnath Wildlife Sanctuary, Nanda Devi Biosphere Reserve, Valley of Flowers National Park, Nada Devi National Park, Gangotri National Park, Govind Widlife Sanctuary, and Askot Wildlife Sanctuary). Surveys were conducted during pre-monsoon (April to June) and post-monsoon (October to November) seasons in 2009, 2010, 2013, 2014, and 2015 . At each survey area, transects with optimal lengths (4-8 km) were walked and talus habitats were searched for direct sighting, as well as indirect evidence (e.g., fecal pellets) of pika occurrence. If pikas or fresh fecal samples were not encountered for more than 1 km during repeated sampling across different years, then the site was considered as absence location. Royle's pika occurrence data (n = 60 georeferenced records) from other regions were collected from the Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF, http://www.gbif.org accessed in 2016), Mammal Networked Information System (MaNIS, http://www. manisnet.org/ accessed in 2016), and published literature (Uniyal 2001; Koju et al. 2014) . Each pika occurrence point collected from a secondary source was verified using Google Earth to ensure that it was located in appropriate talus habitat; if not, the point was discarded (n = 10). Species occurrence locations prior to 1980 were collected through GBIF (record date < January 1980), as well as by interviewing elderly residents (age > 60 years, n = 30) about pika observations around the areas where they lived. The geographic accuracy was confirmed by asking the exact location true to scale (1 km 2 ), where pikas were observed previously.

Recent research revealed that Ochotona himalayana is a sub species of O. roylei (Lissovsky 2014) . Therefore, the distribution range for Royle's pika from the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) was updated by merging the range of these two sub-species (Bhattacharyya and Smith 2018) . Chakraborty et al. (2005) suggested that Royle's pika is distributed along an elevation gradient of 2500 to 5000 m. However, a small number of Royle's pika occurrence locations in the GBIF database indicated a distribution limit as low as 2100 m. Therefore, we adopted a conservative approach by clipping the species distribution range within the elevation gradient of 2000 to 5200 m for further analysis.

We obtained the present climate data representing temperature and precipitation parameters from Worldclim (version 1.4 and version 2.0; http://www.worldclim.org), which provided averaged climate data derived from global and regional weather stations from the years 1970 to 2000, downscaled by using geographic and elevation information at 1 km 2 (Hijmans et al. 2005) .

We used the same set of climate variables at 1-km 2 scale to predict species distribution for two future time periods, 2050 and 2070. Future scenarios were described using various Representative Concentration Pathways (RCPs), which reflected potential emission levels of greenhouse gases projected for the next few decades under different business assumptions (Weyant et al. 2009) . RCPs varied from the most optimistic level of 2.6 W/m 2 (Watts per square meter), which was based upon assumptions of emission reductions after 2020, to the most pessimistic level of 8.5 W/m 2 , which was based upon assumptions that emissions will continue to increase until 2100. All four available RCPs were used (2.6, 4.5, 6.0, and 8.5), in conjunction with one of the most preferred general circulation models (GCMs; AR5, IPCC, 2013), the CCSM4. CCSM4 is known for its accurate climate projections for mega-diverse tropical countries like India (Chaturvedi et al. 2012) . Thus, pika distribution in 2050 and 2070 was estimated using four projections for each timeperiod.

A 90-m digital elevation model (DEM) was obtained from the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission (SRTM). Terrain ruggedness, which represents terrain complexity, was calculated from the DEM and was also resampled to a 1-km resolution (Riley 1999; Ashraf et al. 2018) . We assumed that the terrain ruggedness would remain unchanged in 2050 and 2070, or that any change would be at a minuscule rate that would not influence the habitat at the range scale.

Predictor variables representing both climate and terrain were selected based upon ecologically relevant factors known to influence Royle's pika, or similar talus-dwelling pikas. The spatial scale, source, and relevance of each environmental parameter are provided in Table 1 . Though some predictor variables such as precipitation of coldest quarter were reported to have spatial artifacts (Ribeiro et al. 2017) , we included it in our modeling as it plays important role governing the abundance of the study species (Bhattacharyya et al. 2014a) . No significant correlation was observed among response variables (r < 0.5, Table S1 ) used to model species niche in present and future scenarios. Aspect and slope, two important topographical variables known to influence the distribution of other alpine species, were not incorporated in the final models as they did not show any contribution during the initial steps of the modeling process.

We used a MaxEnt approach (Phillips et al. 2006) to model the current and future climatic niche of Royle's pika. First, we used current species presence locations (i.e., locations recorded after the year 1980) along with climatic and topographic parameters to model the present climatic niche using the linear, quadratic, hinge, and product functions of MaxEnt. These functions were used to retain the species response to various covariates; product feature was retained for smoothing the response. The occurrence locations were clustered in the northwestern Himalayan region, the lower western Himalayan region, and the central Himalayan region. In order to address this spatial bias in occurrence, we mapped the species occurrence on a sampling grid of 1 km 2 . The numbers of records were summed in every grid cell to obtain a "record density." Subsequently, we utilized a cellular automaton, the Moore neighborhood (3 × 3 cells), to estimate the final record density. If the cell had no immediate neighboring records, it was given the value of 0.01 (Kramer-Schadt et al. 2013) . This file was used as a bias file in MaxEnt (Phillips and Dudík 2008; VanDerWal et al. 2009) . We used 10,000 background points randomly drawn from within the region. Out of the total 201 presence records, we used 75% locations (n = 151) for training and 25% locations (n = 50) for cross-validation of the model. We performed 100 bootstrap resampling runs and reported the mean logistic probability and used the area under curve (AUC) score of the receiver operation characteristic (ROC) to assess the model precision (Peterson et al. 2008) . We used Jackknifing to assess the relative contribution of each variable on species occurrence. The regularization function was adjusted to 1, as the model it produced had the highest AUC in the visually most accurate niche model (Elith et al. 2011) .

This model established a relationship between pika occurrence and environmental characteristics and estimated distribution across the Himalayan region. This relationship was projected to the future (e.g., 2050 and 2070) scenarios using similar climatic variables. We used WorldClim version 2, which has a higher accuracy to capture the present climatic variations, to model present climatic niche of Royle's pika (Fick and Hijmans 2017) . Similarly, we also used WorldClim version 1.4 to know the present ecological niche and project four possible niche models for the years 2050 and 2070. The present ecological niche modeled using WorldClim version 1.4 and version 2 yielded significantly (p < 0.1) similar results. Hence, we retained the output of version 1.4, as the future projections were available exclusively for this version. Future scenarios may contain novel climatic areas, which the species has not been previously exposed to; thus, projecting the niche models in such novel areas is erroneous (Elith et al. 2011) . Hence, we used Mobility-Oriented Parity (MOP; Owens et al. 2013) and Multivariate Environmental Similarity Space (MESS) analysis to identify and remove areas of strict extrapolation and in the future scenarios from statistical comparisons (Elith et al. 2011 ). We used "kuenm" package in R (Cobos et al. 2019) for modeling the MOP. The MaxEnt output was a raster with every pixel representing a probability value for potential niche and needs a threshold to be converted into potential presence and absence classes. The omission error for threshold was 10% (E = 10%). Though AIC has been commonly used to select the most parsimonious model that explains the variation in data, it has been criticized for missing the ecological information and resulting in skewed interpretations (Coelho et al. 2019) . Similarly, ROC thresholds can overestimate the niche availability with low number of presence record. In the present study, we have used True Skill Statistics (TSS) which is based on the accuracy of classifying presence and absence record and reported to be more ecologically informed (Allouche et al. 2006) . Following previous studies (Allouche et al. 2006 ), all pixels above a threshold for which TSS was highest, i.e., the correct classification of presence and absence used for model testing model, were categorized as potential niche for pikas. We used the presence locations that were retained for test samples by MaxEnt and the absence locations from field sampling.

We plotted the locations of pika presence before 1980 on the MaxEnt-derived climatic niche for the present scenario (2010-2016). Subsequently, we identified the proportion of past presence locations of pikas, where the niche suitability in the present scenario had been reduced significantly. Royle's pika is a rock talus obligate species with limited dispersal ability due to its small body size and relatively narrow ecological requirements (Bhattacharyya et al. 2014a (Bhattacharyya et al. , 2014b . Therefore, it would be unlikely that the species would be able to expand its distribution limits significantly beyond the current range. We considered the present geographic range of Royle's pika as the maximum limit of dispersal possible in any future climate scenarios. Within this range, we calculated the potential niche area available during three time periods (2010, 2050, and 2070). We classified this area based on elevation (lower elevation 2500-3000 m, mid-elevation 3000-3600 m, high elevation 3600-5000 m), longitude (6 degree intervals; far western Himalaya, western Himalaya, central Himalaya, and eastern Himalaya), and protection status (inside protected areas and outside protected areas). For each class, we estimated the trend in potential area by using an ordinary least square line between the three distribution estimates and used the slope of this trend line to indicate relative changes.
During the field surveys in the Himalayan region, we encountered Royle's pika in four general habitat types (Fig. 3) at elevation ranging from 2650 to 4554 m.

Precipitation of the coldest quarter had the highest contribution to the climatic niche (46.91 ± 7.62%), where the probability of presence increased till 300 mm of precipitation and sharply decrease thereafter (Fig. S1) . Precipitation of the wettest quarter had the second highest contribution (36 ± 9.63%), where the niche suitability increased until 800 mm and gradually decreased after that (Fig. S1) . Temperature seasonality had the next highest contribution (9.78 ± 4.57%), which was negatively related to the niche suitability of Royle's pika (Fig.  S1 ). Maximum temperature of the warmest month had the lowest contribution among climatic variables (6.1 ± 1.59%), where the niche suitability of pika decreased with increase in the temperature. The niche suitability increased initially with an increase in ruggedness and decreased exponentially after that; however, contribution of ruggedness to the model was very low (1.21 ± 0.75%). The area under the receiver operating curve (AUC) for the present (2010) niche model was 0.95 Mean ± 0.02 SD . The maximum TSS threshold, used for converting the continuous niche probability into a binary raster, was 0.20. The accuracy of distinction between absence and presence test points was highest at this threshold with sensitivity 0.92, specificity 0.91, and Kappa statistics of 0.77. All pixels above this value were considered as suitable niche for Royle's pika. This revealed a total area of 35,353 km 2 suitable for Royle's pikas in its range (Fig. 4) . When the historic presence of Royle's pika occurrence (before the year 1980) was contrasted with the present climatic niche (year 2010), 37% of the historic locations had niche suitability lower than the occurrence threshold calculated by TSS (0.20). Even after significantly reducing the threshold by 50% (0.10), there was no change in the results. These locations, with lost niche, were mainly in the far western Himalaya (33%) and central Himalaya (4%; Fig. 4) .

The climatic niche model of Royle's pika for the year 2050 and 2070, under the four RCP scenarios, is provided in Fig.  S2 . The MOP and MESS map (Figs. S3, S4 ) depicts extrapolated areas, which were not captured in the training dataset. Results from this map should be interpreted cautiously, since this area is novel for the predictors and therefore influenced by environmental variables outside the range present in the training data (Elith et al. 2011; Mungi et al. 2018) . Changes in the niche area for the year 2050 and 2070, with respect to the area available in the present scenario, are depicted in Table S2 . Average reduction in the niche availability was 102 km 2/ year across all RCP scenarios, with the highest loss under RCP 8.5 (Fig. 5) . The changes in niche availability were differential with respect to elevation and latitude (Table S2 ). In the far western Himalaya, highest niche loss was observed in the lower elevation range with an average of − 12 ± 4.9 km 2 /year decline across all RCPs, followed by the mid-elevation range (− 9 ± 5.8 km 2 /year). Higher elevation range of far western Himalaya gained suitable area under all RCPs except the RCP 8.5, with an overall gain of 1 ± 3.6 km 2 /year. In the western Himalaya, niche availability decreased with increased emissions under all RCPs in the lower and the mid-elevation ranges (average change across all RCPs was − 8 ± 3.3 km 2 / year and − 16 ± 6.6 km 2 /year, respectively; Table S2 ). In the higher elevation range of the western Himalaya, niche availability increased under RCP 2.6 and RCP 4.5 and decreased under RCP 6.0 and RCP 8.5. Similarly, niche availability declined under all RCPs in the lower and the mid-elevation ranges of the central Himalaya (averaged change across RCPs was − 9.4 ± 2.6 km 2 /year and − 9.2 ± 4.8 km 2 /year) and increased in the higher elevation range under all RCPs, except RCP 6.0, with an average gain of 1.3 ± 1.9 km 2 /year (Table S2 ). In the eastern Himalaya, niche availability significantly declined under all RCPs and across all elevation ranges (Table S2) . Thus, across the species range, niche availability significantly declined in the lower-elevation (− 8 ± 4.8 km 2 / year) and in the mid-elevation ranges (− 10 ± 6.2 km 2 /year). In the higher-elevation range, suitable area increased under the RCP 2.6 and RCP 4.5 in far western, western, and central Himalaya but mostly declined under other RCPs, with an overall decline of − 1 ± 14.5 km 2 /year.

Our results predicted a comparatively higher rate of decrease in suitable areas outside of protected areas (− 74.7 ± 57.7 km 2 /year) than within protected areas (− 27.1 ± 32.6 km 2 /year, Table S2 ). Our predictive model identified that 41% of protected areas, particularly in the north-western (e.g., Dachigam National Park, Manali Wildlife Sanctuary) and the eastern (e.g., Pangolakha Wildlife Sanctuary, Dibang Wildlife Sanctuary) parts of India, might lose 50% to 100% of available niche area for the species by 2070 (Table S3) . A few protected areas in India (e.g., Great Himalayan National Park, A skot Wildlife Sanctuary) were predicted to experience very low (< 3%) to medium (20-30%) loss of available niche area by 2070 ( Supplementary Table S3 ). Furthermore, 30% of protected areas in Nepal (e.g., Annapurna Conservation Area, Api-Nampa Conservation Area) were projected to lose a substantial amount (> 50%) of available niche area by 2070 (Table S3 ). In the Tibetan region of China, an average of > 80% loss of available niche area by 2050 and 2070 was predicted across various RCP scenarios in Chayucibagou Nature Reserve (Table S3 ). Across the RCP scenarios, very few protected areas in the Himalayan region (Pin Valley National Park, Kedarnath Wildlife Sanctuary, Nanda Devi Biosphere Reserve, Govind Pashu Vihar Wildlife Sanctuary, Sangla Wildlife Sanctuary, Gangotri National Park) were projected to gain niche availability (6-30%) in 2050 and 2070 (Table S3 ).

The distribution of montane species is often governed by climate, especially by precipitation, temperature, and other topographical factors such as latitude, elevation, and aspect (Körner 2007; Ray et al. 2012) . Our results suggest that precipitation (coldest quarter, wettest quarter) is the most important variable influencing the niche of Royle's pika across its range in the Himalayan region. Topographical features (e.g., ruggedness), which form the microhabitat architecture, may be crucial at a local scale but are secondary in determining this species' niche at a landscape scale. Nevertheless, the importance of diverse precipitation parameters suggests that Royle's pika niche may be more influenced by indirect effects (e.g., food availability) than direct effects (e.g., summer thermal stress).

The effect of ongoing climate change is heterogeneous and dependent on the geography and species in consideration, and our results offer two examples of divergence from other climate change studies. Firstly, while many other pika species are known to be vulnerable to ongoing changes in temperature, Royle's pika was significantly influenced by higher precipitation in the monsoon and an optimal precipitation in the winter. In the Himalayan region, these precipitation regimes are rapidly changing, with a significant decline projected during the monsoon precipitation (Devaraju et al. 2015) . Secondly, when "warming" is globally used as a synonym for ongoing climatic changes, Himalayan region trends hint towards dual trajectories, where the lower Himalaya is warming and the higher Himalaya is cooling (Devaraju et al. 2015) . This cooling can prolong the winter precipitation effect, thereby making areas unfavorable for Royle's pika. Thus, the popular belief that species adapted to colder areas will shift upwards, as a response to the changing climate (Pecl et al. 2017; Chen et al. 2011) , may not always be consistent.

Very low temperatures during the winter have been found to cause stress in other cold-adapted species (Ray et al. 2012) . Snow cover can act as thermal insulation for animals, as the subnivean environments are often warmer than ambient temperatures. Pikas remain active throughout the winter, and a thick snow cover can provide a protective layer, thus allowing pikas to survive large diel temperature fluctuations during the winter and early spring (Morrison and Hik 2007) . Moreover, insulating snow cover can reduce the amount of energy an animal must spend on thermoregulation in subzero temperatures (Morrison and Hik 2007). The duration of a frost-free season appears to have influenced the demographics of both, Collared pikas (O. collaris) and American pikas (Kreuzer and Huntly 2003; Morrison and Hik 2007) . Beever et al. (2011) found that acute cold stress arising from a thin winter snowpack contributed to localized extirpations of American pika populations in the Great Basin. The duration and depth of snow cover are critical for maintaining nutrient quality in the soil, suggesting a profound effect on alpine plant growth (Walker et al. 1993 (Walker et al. , 1994 . Thick snow cover typically melts slowly, which delays the start of the growing season and reduces frost mortality in herbaceous buds (Inouye 2008) . Thus, winter precipitation helps pikas avoid cold stress and is essential for their food plants to grow during the summer and monsoon period, enabling individuals to persist (Marchand 1996) . While snow cover can positively influence Royle's pika abundance (Bhattacharyya et al. 2013) , prolonged winter snow pack may prohibit foraging and could lead to food scarcity. Our results compliment these observations, where precipitation in the coldest quarter positively influences Royle's pika niche up to a certain threshold, beyond which the niche suitability decreases.
body_text.section: Influence of precipitation on Royle's pika niche

body_text.text: Precipitation is generally high in mountainous areas, and most alpine plants prefer moist environments (Billings and Mooney 1968) . The majority (97.5%) of Royle's pika food plants are forbs that follow the C 3 photosynthetic pathway and depend more on nitrogen and water than plants that follow the C 4 photosynthetic pathway (Bhattacharyya and Smith 2018) . Furthermore, unlike other talus-dwelling pikas, Royle's pika displays a weak affinity for hoarding behavior of winter food sources (Kawamichi 1968; Bhattacharyya et al., 2013) . Hence, availability of food plants during the growing period plays an important role in fulfilling nutritional demands required for successful survival and reproduction. This corroborates our findings indicating that monsoon precipitation during the growing period (the wettest quarter) governs the climatic niche of Royle's pika and explains why areas characterized by more xeric environments (e.g., western Pakistan and the Tibetan plateau) had a lower probability of future suitable habitat availability in comparison to wetter areas (e.g., northern India and Nepal).
body_text.section: Influence of precipitation on Royle's pika niche

body_text.text: Recent climate research in the Himalayan region indicated that average summer precipitation has increased (7.48 mm per year) since 1982, while annual winter precipitation has significantly decreased (− 0.68 mm per year) (Shrestha et al. 2012) . Decreasing winter precipitation may cause more cold stress and increase energy demands in a food-scarce (less C 3 plants) environment, resulting in negative influences on the landscape-level distribution of Royle's pika. Studies also indicate a decline in precipitation intensity in the eastern part of the Himalaya and an increasing trend in the central and western Himalaya (Ren et al. 2017) . This report is consistent with our model results, which indicated a decline in niche availability for Royle's pika in the eastern Himalaya and partial changes in the central and western Himalaya.
body_text.section: Influence of precipitation on Royle's pika niche

body_text.text: These findings related to precipitation suggest the potential for Royle's pika to be used as an indicator species for detecting changes in water resource availability in the Himalayan region. Many of the biggest rivers in Asia are sourced from the Himalayan region, and more than 1.3 billion people depend on this watershed (Bates et al. 2008) . Monitoring efforts so far have relied primarily upon remote-sensing technologies for the holistic assessment of watersheds. However, monitoring the niche of climate sensitive mammals could provide information on attributes of change that may not be detected by monitoring physical factors alone. For example, research on American pikas has documented lower levels of physiological stress in individuals living in habitats underlain by rock glaciers (Wilkening et al. 2015) , an important contributor to downstream water resources. The largest amount of glacial ice outside of the polar realms is located in the Himalayan region, and the rate of glacial retreat has been rapidly increasing (Owen et al. 2002; Ren et al. 2004) . Royle's pika may serve as an early warning indicator of climate change impacts, and monitoring distribution of this species can complement other efforts to model landscape change in watershed areas.
body_text.section: Influence of precipitation on Royle's pika niche

body_text.text: Ambient temperature is considered to be a primary climatic driver that governs the geographical distribution of other pika species (e.g., Beever et al. 2003) . The cooler microclimatic condition of the talus habitat acts as a thermal refuge that allows for behavioral thermoregulation (Rodhouse et al. 2010 ). Royle's pika tends to be most active during the coolest times of the day, as their activity is negatively influenced by higher ambient temperatures and positively influenced by higher ambient moisture (Bhattacharyya et al. 2013 ). This accounts for our observed distribution pattern, where Royle's pika niche was negatively influenced by temperature seasonality and temperature of the warmest quarter. Environmental change research in the Himalayan region has reported a 1.5°C increase in annual temperature from 1982 to 2006, with a disproportionately larger increase (1.75°C) in winter temperatures compared with other seasons (Shrestha et al. 2012) . Summer temperatures are projected to increase under future scenarios of increased greenhouse gas emissions; thus, high temperature seasonality may threaten the climatic niche of Royle's pika across its range. pika distribution increases with terrain ruggedness. Dispersal ability and habitat connectivity are considered important factors in determining the dynamics of a species distribution range in the face of climate change (Schloss et al. 2012 ). Royle's pika is a short-distance disperser (< 2-3 km); habitat connectivity, as well as landscape features, are known to significantly influence their gene flow . Therefore, connectivity between suitable habitat patches or climate refugia at global scales, as well as topographic features (e.g., ruggedness) at local scales, may play a significant role in determining successful adaptation of Royle's pika in the face of changing climatic regimes.
body_text.section: Influence of temperature on Royle's pika niche

body_text.text: Contemporary climatic change research related to other alpine species has typically identified an expansion of species range in high elevation range and a reduction in lower elevation range (Wiens 2016) . Hence, it is believed that climatic niche loss would be greater in low-elevation areas in comparison to higher-elevation areas. This study also demonstrated a similar pattern, as documented by larger losses of suitable climatic niche in lower-elevation habitats under projected climatic change. Royle's pika population decline could have cascading effects on predator species in alpine regions, leading to loss in faunal biodiversity throughout the Himalayan region. Because pikas do not hibernate, they often serve as one of the few winter food sources for carnivores in many alpine areas (Smith et al. 1990) . Lacking a suitable ecological replacement, predators may shift to other regions of higher prey species abundance. In Arctic environments, changes in climatic regime have resulted in decreased prey abundance, which has led to reduced reproductive success and abundance of predators, contributing to localized extinctions (Gilg et al. 2009) . The Himalayan region has higher biodiversity than the global average, with the eastern Himalaya leading in species richness (Barthlott et al. 2007) . Biodiversity declines have already been documented in some alpine ecosystems in the Himalayan region (Xu et al. 2009) , and our results suggest further potential decline.
body_text.section: Priority landscapes for future conservation of Royle's pika

body_text.text: The projected models indicated low availability of suitable niche for Royle's pika within various protected areas in the Himalayan region. Furthermore, Royle's pika is likely to lose more than 50% of the suitable niche inside protected areas in India, Tibet-China, and Nepal. Only a few protected areas in India and Nepal are projected to consistently contain suitable niche under all climate change scenarios (Table S3) . Additionally, our study identified a substantial decrease in suitable habitat outside protected areas. reported extraction of rocks from talus habitat occupied by Royle's pika for various developmental activities in the western Himalaya. Hence, change or alteration of land cover in talus habitat may increase habitat loss and fragmentation outside protected areas and reduce the species' ability to adapt in a changing environment. Our results underscore the importance of recognizing the significance of conservation both within and outside of protected areas, as the traditional practice of conserving wildlife species inside protected areas may be less effective to ensure long-term survival of species in the face of changing environments (Cox and Underwood 2011) . Environmental change adaptation and management recommendations often advocate increasing the number, size, or connectivity of reserves (Pearson and Dawson 2005; Hannah et al. 2007) . Our study identified areas, where future niche availability was projected to increase for Royle's pika, which can be used to prioritize future conservation actions.
body_text.section: Priority landscapes for future conservation of Royle's pika

body_text.text: Though MaxEnt is a robust tool to model the niche or suitable habitat of a species, there are limitations associated with this framework (Pearson et al. 2007 ). Our niche model predicted availability of new niches for the species in high-elevation regions (Table S2 ). Solari and Hadly (2018) also suggested that Royle's pika has efficient cytochrome c oxidase gene proteins, which may allow them to adapt to higher-elevation habitats with low oxygen. Additionally, reported that the upper distribution limit of the majority of Royle's pika food plants was higher than 5000 m. Therefore, availability of sufficient rock cover with suitable crevices, forage plant species, and favorable climatic conditions in higherelevation regions might allow the species to inhabit newly available niches. This does not necessarily indicate all suitable habitats will be accessible to the species as they may face substantial geographic barriers (e.g., lowland valleys) to dispersal . Future studies could utilize high-resolution topographic images, which provide detailed information on rock talus connectivity across landscapes, in order to devise precise distribution models for this species (e.g., Calkins et al. 2012) . In addition, the future climatic scenarios are based on global conditions that may differ from the study area conditions, and caution should be made when interpreting results based on such models (e.g., Schwalm et al. 2016; Stewart et al. 2017) . This is the first detailed scientific study on any Himalayan small mammal species to examine relationships between a species distribution and environmental factors (climatic and topographic), and our results identified possible areas where this species may face significant losses in niche availability in the future. This information will be highly applicable for designing effective conservation and management plans not only for this species but also for other alpine species and will help to assess the speed and magnitude of environmental change in the Himalayan region.
body_text.section: Priority landscapes for future conservation of Royle's pika

FIGREF1.text: Occurrence locations of Royle's pika across its range in the Himalaya (Inset represents geographic location of the study area)

FIGREF2.text: Royle's pika habitat types. a Open rock talus in an alpine meadow. b Walls made of stone or similar human-made structures. (c) Large boulders in Oak-Rhododendron-mixed forest gaps or edges. d Rock talus near glacier moraines

FIGREF3.text: Climatic niche of Royle's pika across its global range as modeled using the present occurrence data and environmental predictors. The subset contrasts the present niche suitability with pika locations before 1980 (blue triangles), where 40% of locations have lost availability of suitable niche in the present scenario

FIGREF4.text: Future (2050 and 2070) climatic niche model of the Royle's pika across its range in the Himalaya, under various representative concentration pathways (RCPs) as estimated from the CCSM4 model. Niche availability decreases with increasing emissions as depicted by increasing RCP scenarios, with maximum reduction under the RCP 8.5
